Documents/Programming/Projects/SSYAlert/Ex-Project-Frameworks/SSYLocalize.framework/Versions/A/Headers/NSString+Localize.h

00001 #import <Cocoa/Cocoa.h>
00002 
00003 /* 
00004  ***** GENERAL DOCUMENTATION ***** 
00005  
00006  ABSTRACT
00007  
00008  This category is my replacement for Cocoa's +[NSString localizedStringWithFormat:] method
00009  and also the NSLocalizedString() macro.  It extends Cocoa's NSString class with five
00010  additional methods.
00011  
00012  DEFINITIONS
00013  
00014  Substitution
00015  
00016  When substring(s) are substituted into a translated string, for example as in:
00017         "Put the %@ in the %@", "apples", "basket"
00018  they are called "substitutions".
00019  
00020  Reordering
00021  
00022  In many cases, the order in which substitutions occur will be different in
00023  in different languages.  For example, consider the English string:
00024     "Put the XXX in the YYY."
00025  No reordering is needed if the translator wants this:
00026     "Putten da XXX inta da YYY"
00027  But in many cases "reordering" is needed because the translator may want something like this:
00028     "Inta da YYY putten da XXX"
00029  The problem of Reordering requires that the placeholders be somehow indexed.
00030  
00031  MOTIVATIONS
00032  
00033  1.  Simpler Reorderable Strings
00034  
00035  In Apple documentation Internationalization Programming Topics > Strings Files, Apple
00036  states their solution to the problem of Reordering (described above):
00037  "The translator can reorder the arguments in the translated string if that is necessary.
00038  If a string contains multiple arguments, the translated string can use the
00039      [n][$] modifier[] n$
00040  modifier for each argument, where n indicates the position of the original argument."
00041  Actually, it's not quite as bad as that says.  In fact, after the modifier comes
00042  immediately the format character (f, e, d, etc.)  If the argument is an NSString,
00043  the required placeholders are %0$@, %1$@, etc.  These are ghastly.  They become worse when
00044  you actually use the modifiers, for example $%0$7.2f.  I sure as hell can't type them
00045  very fast without making lots of mistakes.  And, since the above-referenced Apple
00046  documentation is so confusing, I'd have to re-document it for our translators anyhow.
00047  I don't like to explain things that are ghastly.
00048  
00049  So, one motivation is to also support the "Classic Mac OS" placeholders %0, %1, %2, 
00050  which are much easier to use, even though they only allow strings to be substituted.
00051  In practice, this is a small limitation because > 98% of substitutions in most apps
00052  are strings anyhow, and the remaining 2% are mostly integers which can be handily
00053  converted to strings using +[NSString stringWithInt:] provided herein.  The very rare
00054  case of floats, etc. can be preprocessed with [NSString localizedStringWithFormat:].
00055  And my implementation of +[NSString localizeFormat:] still supports the ghastly Apple
00056  syntax for those that really want to use it.
00057  
00058  2.  Get the Localization Comments out of the Code
00059  
00060  I have no use for the 'comments' argument in NSLocalizedString because I prefer to carefully
00061  re-use my strings based on comments which I enter directly into a common Localizable.strings
00062  file.  My comments are sometimes very long and therefore would make my code hard to read if
00063  there were in every NSLocalizedString() call.  I consider my comments to be a property of the
00064  string key, not of any particular instantiated use, and that it is the responsiblity of the
00065  person writing the code to check that the "documentation", i.e. comments, defining a particular
00066  key before using it.  There are two other alternatives: (1) Never re-use any translations.
00067  (2) Have translators review the everyting whenever the app is updated.  My localization
00068  budget does not allow these other alternatives. 
00069  
00070  Of course, re-used translations can be poor if you don't define a broad enough scope
00071  for your translators in your comments, and have some knowledge of international
00072  linguistics to help you judge what can be generalized. But, again, my localization budget
00073  cannot afford perfection.
00074  
00075  Thus having dispensed with genstrings, I am tired of typing ", nil" in every call to
00076  NSLocalizedString(). 
00077  
00078 
00079  TEST CODE AND EXAMPLES
00080  
00081  *** To run these tests, paste the following definitions into project's Localizable.strings:
00082  
00083  "yessir" = "Oui" ;
00084  "putStuff" = "Inta da %2 afteren %0 putten %3%% of da %1." ;
00085  "destroy" = "We had to destroy the %0 in order to save the %0." ;
00086  "show123" = "first: %@.  second: %@.  third: %@." ;
00087  "unsignedLongz" = "Unsigned long numbers:\nlittleu: %u\n   bigU: %U\nlittlex: %x\n   bigX: %X\nlittleo: %o\n   bigO: %O\n self: %p" ;
00088  "putApple" = "Inta da %2$@ afteren %0$@ putten %3$d%% of da %1$@." ;
00089  "youHaveInteger" = "You have: %1$8i %0$@." ;
00090  "youHaveFloat" = "You have: $%1$7.2f %0$@ in your %2$@." ;
00091  "theFractions" = "Your fraction of the %2$@ is %1$0.3e and mine is %0$0.3e." ;
00092  
00093  *** And paste this code where it will execute:
00094  
00095  #import "SSYLocalize/NSString+Localize.h"
00096  
00097  NSString* s ;
00098  
00099  // Basic, no substitutions
00100  // Relevant entry in Localizable.strings:
00101  // "yessir" = "Oui" ;
00102  s = [NSString localize:@"yessir"] ;
00103  NSLog(@"%@", s) ;
00104  
00105  // Using the localizeFormat: when there are no subs
00106  // Wasteful, but works the same
00107  s = [NSString localizeFormat:@"yessir"] ;
00108  NSLog(@"%@", s) ;
00109  
00110  // Nil-terminate the argument list if you want to.
00111  // Nil termination is not necessary.
00112  s = [NSString localizeFormat:@"yessir", nil] ;
00113  NSLog(@"%@", s) ;
00114  
00115  // Simple reorderable string substitutions: %0, %1, %2, ...
00116  // also demonstrates a literal (escaped) percent %%
00117  // and preprocessing an integer using +[NSString stringWithInt:]
00118  // Relevant entry in Localizable.strings:
00119  // "putStuff" = "Inta da %2 afteren %0 putten %3%% of da %1." ;
00120  s = [NSString localizeFormat:@"putStuff",
00121  @"you're done",
00122  @"peanuts",
00123  @"bucket",
00124  [NSString stringWithInt:80]] ;
00125  NSLog(@"%@", s) ;
00126  
00127  // Reorderable string arguments will be re-used if not enough
00128  // are supplied in the argument list.
00129  // Relevant entry in Localizable.strings:
00130  // "destroy" = "We had to destroy the %0 in order to save the %0." ;
00131  s = [NSString localizeFormat:@"destroy",
00132  @"village"] ;
00133  NSLog(@"%@", s) ;
00134  
00135  // Simpler nonreorderable string substitutions: %@, %@, %@, ...
00136  // Relevant entry in Localizable.strings:
00137  // "show123" = "first: %@.  second: %@.  third: %@." ;
00138  s = [NSString localizeFormat:@"show123",
00139  @"alpha",
00140  @"beta",
00141  @"gamma"] ;
00142  NSLog(@"%@", s) ;
00143  
00144  // Error indicated if missing entry in Localizable.strings
00145  s = [NSString localizeFormat:@"Oops some %@ forgot to enter a string for %@.",
00146  @"This substring will not be used."] ;
00147  NSLog(@"%@", s) ;
00148  
00149  // "unsignedLongz" = "Unsigned long numbers:\nlittleu: %u\n   bigU: %U\nlittlex: %x\n   bigX: %X\nlittleo: %o\n   bigO: %O\n self: %p" ;
00150  s = [NSString localizeFormat:@"unsignedLongz",
00151  0xFFFFFF00,
00152  0xFFFFFF01,
00153  0xFFFFFF02,
00154  0xFFFFFF03,
00155  0xFFFFFF04,
00156  0xFFFFFF05,
00157  self] ;
00158  NSLog(@"%@", s) ;
00159  
00160  // Remaining tests use Apple's ("ghastly") syntax (%n$x.yz) for reordering 
00161  // substitutions.  It is messy but allows arbitrary format specifiers.
00162  
00163  // Re-do the peanuts in the bucket example, with apples
00164  // Relevant entry in Localizable.strings:
00165  // "putApple" = "Inta da %2$@ afteren %0$@ putten %3$d%% of da %1$@." ;
00166  s = [NSString localizeFormat:@"putApple",
00167  @"you're done",
00168  @"apples",
00169  @"bucket",
00170  80] ;
00171  NSLog(@"%@", s) ;
00172  
00173  
00174  // Relevant entry in Localizable.strings:
00175  // "youHaveInteger" = "You have: %1$8i %0$@." ;
00176  s = [NSString localizeFormat:@"youHaveInteger",
00177  @"toes",
00178  10] ;
00179  NSLog(@"%@", s) ;      
00180  // Relevant entry in Localizable.strings:
00181  // "youHaveFloat" = "You have: $%1$7.2f %0$@ in your %2$@." ;
00182  s = [NSString localizeFormat:@"youHaveFloat",
00183  @"dollars",
00184  14.95123,  // floats are promoted to double by ...
00185  @"pocket"] ;
00186  NSLog(@"%@", s) ;
00187  // Relevant entry in Localizable.strings:
00188  // "theFractions" = "Your fraction of the %2$@ is %1$0.3e and mine is %0$0.3e." ;
00189  s = [NSString localizeFormat:@"theFractions",
00190  .56789,
00191  1.2345e-5,
00192  @"pie"] ;
00193  NSLog(@"%@", s) ;
00194  
00195  NSLog(@"\nTest suite for SSLocalizable is done.") ;
00196  
00197  */
00198 
00199 
00200 @interface NSString (SSYLocalize)
00201 
00202 /* 
00203  Returns a localized string built from formatString and placeholder substitutions
00204  If formatString
00205    - is nil, this method will return nil.
00206    - is an empty string, this method will return the same empty string.
00207  
00208  Otherwise, will search the "Localizable.strings" resources in the framework bundle which 
00209  is named "SSYLocalize" (i.e. one which has a path of the form:
00210  "/path/to/SSYLocalize.framework).  If formatString is not found,
00211  this method will return formatString capitalized (UPPER CASE) and followed by 
00212  " <NOT FOUND>", and will also log the error to stderr.
00213  
00214  If formatString is found, will process as explained below.
00215 
00216  This method will parse formatString for percent ("%") characters which denote
00217  placeholders.  Placeholders will be parsed out (in this order):
00218     literal % characters by escaping; i.e. %%.
00219         nonreorderable NSString placeholders %@
00220     reorderable NSString placeholders %0, %1, %2, ... , %9.
00221         reorderable arbitrary placeholders n$[modifier][formatChar]
00222                 Examples: %0$@, %1$@, $%0$7.2f
00223 
00224  For formatChar, all of the single-character Format Specifiers listed in:
00225         String Programming Guide For Cocoa > String Format Specifiers 
00226         > Format Specifiers > Table 1
00227  are supported.  Specifically, these are:
00228         @, c, C, d, D, i, e, f, F, g, G, s, S, p, u, U, x, X, o, O
00229 
00230  The same reorderable placeholder may be used more than once, for example,
00231         "We had to destroy the %0 in order to save the %0."
00232 
00233  There is no need to nil-terminate the argument list.
00234   
00235  DISCUSSION
00236  
00237  As is typical of methods based on va_arg, it's easy to cause a crash.  Here,
00238  the number of placeholders with unique index numbers in in the first argument
00239  (the format string) must be <= number of remaining arguments (placeholder
00240  substitutions).  (The alternative design is to require that argument lists
00241  be nil-terminated, but that often results in crashes too.)  For example, the
00242  following formatString will cause a crash if it is not followed by at least
00243  two arguments:
00244      "We had to destroy the %@ in order to save the %@."
00245  
00246  You can still use the simple reorderable NSString placeholders %0, %1, %2,...
00247  to process numbers by preprocessing the arguments.
00248  If you want to substitute in an integer, preprocess it with
00249       +[NSString stringWithInt:].
00250  If you want to substitute in a float, preprocess it with 
00251       +[NSString localizedStringWithFormat:],
00252  which will give a string "locale-ized" to the user's default locale.
00253  For example, the decimal point may be a comma in some locales.
00254 
00255 */
00256 + (NSString*)localizeFormat:(NSString*)formatString, ... ;
00257 
00258 /*
00259  Same as localizeFormat:, except that if formatString is not found in any relevant
00260  "Localizable.strings", will return formatString and will not log anything
00261  to stderr.
00262 */
00263 + (NSString*)weaklyLocalizeFormat:(NSString*)formatString, ... ;
00264 
00265 /*
00266  Convenient and cheaper-running method for when there are no substitutions. 
00267  keyString should be a key in Localizable.strings.
00268  keyString may include literal percent characters (%) without escaping. 
00269 */
00270 + (NSString*)localize:(NSString*)keyString ;
00271 
00272 /*
00273  Same as localize:, except that if keyString is not found in any relevant
00274  "Localizable.strings", will return formatString and will not log anything
00275  to stderr.
00276 */
00277 + (NSString*)weaklyLocalize:(NSString*)keyString ;
00278 
00279 /*
00280  Returns the nominal two-letter code of the language which is loaded and currently
00281  running in the application.  Actually, it simply returns the value of the entry
00282  in Localizable.strings for the key "000_language", but if this entry is missing
00283  it returns "en" (for English).
00284 */
00285 + (NSString*)languageCodeLoaded ;
00286 
00287 /*
00288  returns a string representation of the integer.  Examples: "1" "42", "-579".
00289 */
00290 + (NSString*)stringWithInt:(int)i ;
00291 
00292 @end
00293
